Introduction

Endometriosis is a chronic gynecologic condition affecting approximately 10% of reproductive-aged women and is characterized by the presence of extrauterine (or ectopic) endometrial glands and stroma.  It is often found within the pelvic cavity and, less commonly, distant organs (eg, diaphragm).  Endometriosis has a variety of clinical presentations, ranging from an asymptomatic, incidental finding to severe pelvic pain and infertility.

Pathophysiology



Endometriosis is characterized by ectopic (

figure 1
) endometrial glands and stroma typically found in the pelvis, most commonly on the ovaries, anterior and posterior cul-de-sacs, and broad and uterosacral ligaments.  They can also be found on the bladder, fallopian tubes, bowel, and peritoneum.  Several theories have been proposed to explain the appearance of endometrial tissue in extrauterine locations; these include:



  • Retrograde menstruation:  backward menstrual blood flow from the uterine cavity through the fallopian tubes, which introduces endometrial cells to the pelvic cavity.

  • Coelomic metaplasia:  peritoneal cells transform into endometrial-like cells.

  • MÃ¼llerian embryonic rests:  MÃ¼llerian tissue left along the path of migration during embryogenesis proliferates and becomes ectopic endometrial tissue.

  • Lymphatic and vascular spread:  endometrial cells spread via lymphatic or blood vessels.  This theory explains the occurrence of endometriosis at distant, extraperitoneal sites.



The development of ectopic endometriotic lesions is likely multifactorial and likely involves impaired clearance of the ectopic endometrial cells and complex interactions between hormonal, inflammatory, and nervous system signaling pathways.



Because the lesions are hormonally responsive, the intraperitoneal implants proliferate and shed during menses; however, because there is no outlet, progressive fibrosis and adhesions develop, which leads to subsequent distortion of pelvic anatomy and long-term complications (eg, infertility, chronic pain).

Risk factors



  • Family history

  • Anatomic factors:  outflow tract disorders (eg, cervical stenosis, mÃ¼llerian anomalies), which increase the likelihood of retrograde menstruation

  • Increased estrogen exposure:  early menarche, late menopause, and nulliparity (conversely, decreased estrogen exposure [eg, late menarche, extended lactation, multiple birth] is protective)

Clinical presentation



Endometriosis has a wide range of symptoms from completely asymptomatic (and incidentally found during surgery) to chronic, debilitating pain:



  • Dysmenorrhea:  typically severe, potentially unilateral, and occurring throughout menses

  • Chronic pelvic pain

  • Dyspareunia, particularly with deep penetration

  • Infertility:  due to anatomic distortions from adhesions, ovarian dysfunction, and chronic inflammation (increased inflammatory cytokines impair ovulation, fertilization, and implantation)



Additional symptoms may occur due to the ectopic location of the endometriosis implants:



  • Bladder:  may cause urinary frequency, hesitancy, or painful micturition.  Deeply implanted lesions may result in frank hematuria.

  • Intestine/rectum:  may cause diarrhea, constipation, tenesmus, painful defecation, or hematochezia.

  • Lungs:  chest pain or hemoptysis due to implants within the chest cavity.

Diagnosis



A definitive diagnosis of endometriosis is made by histologic evaluation of surgical specimens demonstrating endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterus.  However, because a definitive diagnosis typically requires invasive surgery, a presumptive diagnosis is frequently made based on history, physical examination, and, potentially, imaging.

Physical examination



Classic physical examination findings include:



  • Localized pelvic tenderness.

  • Uterosacral ligament nodularity (often palpated on or in posterior fornix).

  • Fixed, immobile uterus on bimanual examination (due to pelvic adhesions).  In patients with severe adhesions, this can cause the cervix to become laterally displaced.

  • Adnexal masses due to the formation of endometriomas.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging



No laboratory studies are helpful in diagnosing endometriosis.



Imaging is not always necessary; however, pelvic ultrasonographyis the ideal imaging modality when an adnexal mass is suspected or palpated.  On ultrasonography, endometriomas (

image 1
) appear as unilocular cysts with a ground glass (homogenous, isoechoic) appearance (from internal hemorrhagic debris).



In patients who have severe symptoms or whose condition does not respond to standard therapies, surgical evaluation may be required to establish the diagnosis.  In addition to direct visualization and biopsy of lesions for definitive diagnosis, surgery also allows for possible simultaneous treatment.  However, the appearance of endometriosis is highly variable; more important, its appearance does not correlate to the degree of symptoms, particularly pain. Lesions may appear as:



  • Superficial, translucent blebs; small peritoneal cysts or nodules; or red, white, or blue-brown ("powder-burn") lesions

  • Deeply infiltrating nodules (extending below the peritoneal surface)

  • Endometriomas, or ovarian endometriosis implants that form a cystic collection of brown fluid and debris referred to as chocolate cysts (

    image 2
    )

  • Adhesions

  • Puckered peritoneal surfaces or peritoneal defects

Histopathology



Definitive diagnosis is made through the histologic (

image 3
) appearance of extrauterine endometrial glands and stroma with varying amounts of inflammation, fibrosis, and hemosiderin-laden macrophages.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of endometriosis is based on its presenting symptoms and can be divided based on its symptoms.

Dysmenorrhea and/or chronic pelvic pain



  • Primary dysmenorrhea:  in contrast to endometriosis, patients have bilateral, midline pelvic pain only during the first 2-3 days of the menstrual cycle.

  • Adenomyosis (

    figure 2
    ): typically presents with heavy, painful menses.  Examination often shows a tender, boggy, globular uterus instead of the tender, fixed, immobile uterus with endometriosis.

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease:  typically presents with acute (rather than chronic) pelvic pain, mucopurulent cervical discharge, and fever.

  • Irritable bowel syndrome and inflammatory bowel disease:  Both conditions can cause chronic pelvic pain; however, the predominant symptoms are gastrointestinal (eg, diarrhea, constipation, flatulence, hematochezia).  However, the pain is more likely to occur in association with defecation (rather than with menstruation), and neither causes a tender, immobile uterus or pelvic nodularity.

  • Interstitial cystitis:  causes chronic pelvic pain; however, the pain is classically related to bladder filling and is relieved with micturition.  There may be tenderness with bladder palpation on bimanual examination; however, there is no associated fixed, immobile uterus or pelvic nodularity.

Ovarian mass



Ovarian cysts can mimic endometriosis by causing pelvic pain and an adnexal mass on pelvic examination.  The ultrasonographic appearance can help distinguish between the etiologies:



  • Follicular cyst:  smooth, thin-walled cyst containing homogenous anechoic fluid that often resolves within several weeks.

  • Dermoid cyst (mature teratoma):  cyst that contains heterogeneous contents with hyperechoic nodules and/or calcifications (consistent with adipose tissue and cartilage).

  • Malignancy:  cysts with solid components, internal vascularity, papillary projections, or thick septations.  May be accompanied by bloating, ascites, early satiety, and weight loss.

Management



Treatment should not be delayed for histologic diagnosis in patients with classic symptoms of endometriosis.  Medical management is the mainstay of treatment because endometriosis is a chronic condition; repeated surgical interventions should be minimized because surgery can worsen adhesion formation.



Medical management (

figure 3
) is considered maintenance therapy for individuals not desiring immediate conception and involves:



  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

  • Combined estrogen/progestin oral contraceptive pills or progestin-only treatments (eg, depo-medroxyprogesterone):  suppresses menstruation and may cause atrophy of ectopic endometrium.

  • GnRH agonists and antagonists: used in patients with severe endometriosis or those with pain refractory to treatment with hormonal contraceptives and NSAIDs.  These medications suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis and induce a hypoestrogenic state, which causes amenorrhea and endometrial atrophy.  However, they cause significant adverse effects related to the hypoestrogenic state (eg, vasomotor symptoms, bone density loss), which often limit long-term use.



Surgical treatment with removal or ablation of the endometrial implants often provides short-term relief in patients, but symptoms recur without medical maintenance therapy.  Therefore, surgery is reserved for patients with severe symptoms, those who have adnexal masses, and those who desire conception (ie, endometrioma removal, adhesion release).  In addition, definitive surgical management (eg, hysterectomy Â± salpingo-oophorectomy) may be considered in patients with refractory disease and debilitating pain.



In patients with infertility, a full infertility evaluation of both partners is required because endometriosis may not be the only factor contributing to infertility.  Some patients may require surgical treatment of endometriosis or advanced reproductive assistance (eg, in vitro fertilization).

Prognosis



Endometriosis is a lifelong chronic condition with a highly variable course. The symptoms can fluctuate with frequent recurrences.  It has a significant impact on quality of life and affects physical and emotional well-being, making concurrent depression and anxiety highly likely.  Most patients experience some improvement in symptoms during pregnancy and with natural menopause.  Patients with endometriosis have a small but increased risk for ovarian cancer, particularly ovarian clear cell carcinoma and ovarian endometrioid carcinoma.

Summary



Endometriosis (
